text: Mario J. Molina (March 19, 1943 - October 7, 2020) was a Mexican chemist who won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1995 with Paul J. Crutzen and F. Sherwood Rowland. This was because, in the 1970s, he was one of the scientists who discovered that there was a hole in the ozone layer in the Earth's atmosphere. He is the first Mexican to receive the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Molina was one of 20 Nobel LaureatesSuch as Peter Agre, Nadine Gordimer, Yuan T. Lee, Elinor Ostrom, Werner Arber, David Gross, James Mirrlees, Carlo Rubbia, Paul J. Crutzen, Amartya Sen, Peter Doherty (scientist), Walter Kohn, Douglass North, John Sulston, Murray Gell-Mann, Harold Kroto, Douglas Osheroff, Muhammad Yunus who signed the "Stockholm memorandum" at the 3rd Nobel Laureate Symposium on Global Sustainability in Stockholm, Sweden on 18 May 2011."Stockholm Memorandum," Nobel-cause.de, 2011 Molina led a committee of the American Association for the Advancement of Science which released a stark report on global warming March 2014.Scientists Sound Alarm on Climate March 18, 2014 NYT Molina was born in Mexico City. He studied at National Autonomous University of Mexico, University of Freiburg and at the University of California, Berkeley. Molina died in Mexico City from a heart attack on October 7, 2020 at the age of 77. ==References== Category:1943 birthsk Category:2020 deaths Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction Category:Chemists Category:Mexican Nobel Prize winners Category:Mexican scientists
